\documentclass[11pt]{article}

    
    
    \usepackage[T1]{fontenc}
    % Nicer default font (+ math font) than Computer Modern for most use cases
    \usepackage{mathpazo}

    % Basic figure setup, for now with no caption control since it's done
    % automatically by Pandoc (which extracts ![](path) syntax from Markdown).
    \usepackage{graphicx}
    % We will generate all images so they have a width \maxwidth. This means
    % that they will get their normal width if they fit onto the page, but
    % are scaled down if they would overflow the margins.
    \makeatletter
    \def\maxwidth{\ifdim\Gin@nat@width>\linewidth\linewidth
    \else\Gin@nat@width\fi}
    \makeatother
    \let\Oldincludegraphics\includegraphics
    % Set max figure width to be 80% of text width, for now hardcoded.
    \renewcommand{\includegraphics}[1]{\Oldincludegraphics[width=.8\maxwidth]{#1}}
    % Ensure that by default, figures have no caption (until we provide a
    % proper Figure object with a Caption API and a way to capture that
    % in the conversion process - todo).
    \usepackage{caption}
    \DeclareCaptionLabelFormat{nolabel}{}
    \captionsetup{labelformat=nolabel}

    \usepackage{adjustbox} % Used to constrain images to a maximum size 
    \usepackage{xcolor} % Allow colors to be defined
    \usepackage{enumerate} % Needed for markdown enumerations to work
    \usepackage{geometry} % Used to adjust the document margins
    \usepackage{amsmath} % Equations
    \usepackage{amssymb} % Equations
    \usepackage{textcomp} % defines textquotesingle
    % Hack from http://tex.stackexchange.com/a/47451/13684:
    \AtBeginDocument{%
        \def\PYZsq{\textquotesingle}% Upright quotes in Pygmentized code
    }
    \usepackage{upquote} % Upright quotes for verbatim code
    \usepackage{eurosym} % defines \euro
    \usepackage[mathletters]{ucs} % Extended unicode (utf-8) support
    \usepackage[utf8x]{inputenc} % Allow utf-8 characters in the tex document
    \usepackage{fancyvrb} % verbatim replacement that allows latex
    \usepackage{grffile} % extends the file name processing of package graphics 
                         % to support a larger range 
    % The hyperref package gives us a pdf with properly built
    % internal navigation ('pdf bookmarks' for the table of contents,
    % internal cross-reference links, web links for URLs, etc.)
    \usepackage{hyperref}
    \usepackage{longtable} % longtable support required by pandoc >1.10
    \usepackage{booktabs}  % table support for pandoc > 1.12.2
    \usepackage[inline]{enumitem} % IRkernel/repr support (it uses the enumerate* environment)
    \usepackage[normalem]{ulem} % ulem is needed to support strikethroughs (\sout)
                                % normalem makes italics be italics, not underlines
    

    
    
    % Colors for the hyperref package
    \definecolor{urlcolor}{rgb}{0,.145,.698}
    \definecolor{linkcolor}{rgb}{.71,0.21,0.01}
    \definecolor{citecolor}{rgb}{.12,.54,.11}

    \newcommand{\OperatorTok}[1]{\textcolor[rgb]{0.40,0.40,0.40}{{#1}}}
    \newcommand{\BuiltInTok}[1]{{#1}}
    \newcommand{\ExtensionTok}[1]{{#1}}

    \newcommand{\InformationTok}[1]{\textcolor[rgb]{0.38,0.63,0.69}{\textbf{\textit{{#1}}}}}
    \newcommand{\WarningTok}[1]{\textcolor[rgb]{0.38,0.63,0.69}{\textbf{\textit{{#1}}}}}

\def\PY@reset{\let\PY@it=\relax \let\PY@bf=\relax%
    \let\PY@ul=\relax \let\PY@tc=\relax%
    \let\PY@bc=\relax \let\PY@ff=\relax}
\def\PY@tok#1{\csname PY@tok@#1\endcsname}
\def\PY@toks#1+{\ifx\relax#1\empty\else%
    \PY@tok{#1}\expandafter\PY@toks\fi}
\def\PY@do#1{\PY@bc{\PY@tc{\PY@ul{%
    \PY@it{\PY@bf{\PY@ff{#1}}}}}}}
\def\PY#1#2{\PY@reset\PY@toks#1+\relax+\PY@do{#2}}

    \begin{document}
    
    
    \maketitle
    
    

    
    \section{KT-15 Calibration Dependence on Housing
Temperature}\label{kt-15-calibration-dependence-on-housing-temperature}

    Whenever we do a calibration, we find that the KT15 over-estimates cold
temperatures and under-estimates warm temperatures (see the blue dots
above the orange line at low temps, but blue dots below the orange line
at high temps):

\begin{figure}
\centering
\includegraphics{KT15_Calibration_2020-10-30_7417_7409.png}
\caption{alt}
\end{figure}

There is thus always a point somewhere in the middle of the calibration
line where the KT15 measurement equals the blackbody temperature
exactly. It appears that this "neutral calibration point" (aka the
temperature at which applying the calibration has no effect) is related
to the housing temperature:

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{incolor}In [{\color{incolor}172}]:} \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{}create fake data array to apply the calibration to}
          \PY{n}{data} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{np}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{linspace}\PY{p}{(}\PY{l+m+mi}{0}\PY{p}{,}\PY{l+m+mi}{40}\PY{p}{,} \PY{l+m+mi}{1000}\PY{p}{)}
          
          \PY{n}{zero\PYZus{}crosses\PYZus{}7409} \PY{o}{=} \PY{p}{[}\PY{p}{]}
          \PY{k}{for} \PY{n}{num} \PY{o+ow}{in} \PY{n}{np}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{arange}\PY{p}{(}\PY{l+m+mi}{0}\PY{p}{,}\PY{n+nb}{len}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{cals\PYZus{}7409}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{:}
              \PY{n}{cal} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{cals\PYZus{}7409}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{iloc}\PY{p}{[}\PY{n}{num}\PY{p}{]}
              \PY{n}{calibrated} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{cal}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{slope}\PY{o}{*}\PY{n}{data} \PY{o}{+} \PY{n}{cal}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{yint}
              \PY{n}{diff} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{calibrated}\PY{o}{\PYZhy{}}\PY{n}{data}
              \PY{n}{zero\PYZus{}cross\PYZus{}ind} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{np}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{where}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{np}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{diff}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{np}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{sign}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{diff}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{[}\PY{l+m+mi}{0}\PY{p}{]}
              \PY{n}{zero\PYZus{}crossing} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{data}\PY{p}{[}\PY{n}{zero\PYZus{}cross\PYZus{}ind}\PY{p}{]}
              \PY{n}{zero\PYZus{}crosses\PYZus{}7409}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{append}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{zero\PYZus{}crossing}\PY{p}{)}
          \PY{n}{cals\PYZus{}7409}\PY{p}{[}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{zero\PYZus{}crossing}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{]} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{zero\PYZus{}crosses\PYZus{}7409}
          
          
          \PY{n}{zero\PYZus{}crosses\PYZus{}7417} \PY{o}{=} \PY{p}{[}\PY{p}{]}
          \PY{k}{for} \PY{n}{num} \PY{o+ow}{in} \PY{n}{np}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{arange}\PY{p}{(}\PY{l+m+mi}{0}\PY{p}{,}\PY{n+nb}{len}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{cals\PYZus{}7417}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{:}
              \PY{n}{cal} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{cals\PYZus{}7417}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{iloc}\PY{p}{[}\PY{n}{num}\PY{p}{]}
              \PY{n}{calibrated} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{cal}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{slope}\PY{o}{*}\PY{n}{data} \PY{o}{+} \PY{n}{cal}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{yint}
              \PY{n}{diff} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{calibrated}\PY{o}{\PYZhy{}}\PY{n}{data}
              \PY{n}{zero\PYZus{}cross\PYZus{}ind} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{np}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{where}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{np}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{diff}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{np}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{sign}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{diff}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{[}\PY{l+m+mi}{0}\PY{p}{]}
              \PY{n}{zero\PYZus{}crossing} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{data}\PY{p}{[}\PY{n}{zero\PYZus{}cross\PYZus{}ind}\PY{p}{]}
              \PY{n}{zero\PYZus{}crosses\PYZus{}7417}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{append}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{zero\PYZus{}crossing}\PY{p}{)}
          \PY{n}{cals\PYZus{}7417}\PY{p}{[}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{zero\PYZus{}crossing}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{]} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{zero\PYZus{}crosses\PYZus{}7417}
          
          \PY{n}{fig}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{axx} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{plt}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{subplots}\PY{p}{(}\PY{p}{)}
          \PY{n}{plt}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{scatter}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{cals\PYZus{}7409}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{housing}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{cals\PYZus{}7409}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{zero\PYZus{}crossing}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{c}\PY{o}{=}\PY{n}{mdates}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{date2num}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{cals\PYZus{}7409}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{index}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{cmap}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{tab10}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{)}
          \PY{n}{plt}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{scatter}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{cals\PYZus{}7417}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{housing}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{cals\PYZus{}7417}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{zero\PYZus{}crossing}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{c}\PY{o}{=}\PY{n}{mdates}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{date2num}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{cals\PYZus{}7417}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{index}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{cmap}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{tab10}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{marker}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{*}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{s}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+m+mi}{60}\PY{p}{)}
          \PY{n}{plt}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{plot}\PY{p}{(}\PY{p}{[}\PY{l+m+mi}{25}\PY{p}{,}\PY{l+m+mi}{35}\PY{p}{]}\PY{p}{,}\PY{p}{[}\PY{l+m+mi}{25}\PY{p}{,}\PY{l+m+mi}{35}\PY{p}{]}\PY{p}{,}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{gray}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{)}

          \PY{n}{plt}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{xlabel}\PY{p}{(}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{Housing Temperature}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{)}
          \PY{n}{plt}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{ylabel}\PY{p}{(}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{Zero\PYZhy{}Crossing Temperature (}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZdq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{Neutral Point}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZdq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{)}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{)}
          \PY{n}{plt}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{title}\PY{p}{(}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{Calibration Neutral Point vs. Housing Temperature}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{)}
          
          \PY{n}{plt}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{tight\PYZus{}layout}\PY{p}{(}\PY{p}{)}
\end{Verbatim}


    \begin{center}
    \adjustimage{max size={0.9\linewidth}{0.9\paperheight}}{output_2_0.png}
    \end{center}
    { \hspace*{\fill} \\}
    
    This relationship suggests that it is inappropriate to apply a
calibration done at a certain housing temperature to a dataset taken at
a different housing temperature. Applying a 25-degree calibration to a
35-degree dataset could easily lead us to overestimate the temperature
by 0.5-1 degree! Looking at the housing temperatures on DYNAMO, it's
clear that most of our calibrations aren't applicable:

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{incolor}In [{\color{incolor}171}]:} \PY{n}{plt}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{hist}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{kt\PYZus{}dynamo}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{SeaRef}\PY{p}{)} \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{}7409}
          \PY{n}{plt}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{hist}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{kt\PYZus{}dynamo}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{SkyRef}\PY{p}{)} \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{}7417}
          \PY{n}{plt}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{legend}\PY{p}{(}\PY{p}{[}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{7409}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{,}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{7417}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{]}\PY{p}{)}
          \PY{n}{plt}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{title}\PY{p}{(}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{DYNAMO Housing Temperature Distribution}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{;}
\end{Verbatim}


    \begin{center}
    \adjustimage{max size={0.9\linewidth}{0.9\paperheight}}{output_4_0.png}
    \end{center}
    { \hspace*{\fill} \\}
    
    Since the distribution of housing temperatures is centered near 36
degrees, I then tried calibrating our dataset just with the two
calibrations centered on 36 and 40 degrees (July 2020 and March 2021,
respectively). This leads to significant improvement in the agreement
between sea snake and KT15 measurements:

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

    \begin{center}
    \adjustimage{max size={0.9\linewidth}{0.9\paperheight}}{output_6_1.png}
    \end{center}
    { \hspace*{\fill} \\}
    
    Finally, I also wanted to try just sky-correcting the data without
applying a lab calibration for comparison. We can see that applying the
\textbf{right} calibration does seem to improve agreement compared to
not calibrating at all:

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{incolor}In [{\color{incolor}40}]:} \PY{o}{\PYZpc{}}\PY{k}{autoreload}
         \PY{k+kn}{from} \PY{n+nn}{KT15\PYZus{}Toolbox} \PY{k}{import} \PY{n}{KT15\PYZus{}skycorrect82}
         
         \PY{n}{KT15\PYZus{}skycorrect82}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{l1data\PYZus{}path} \PY{o}{=} \PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{../Data/Level\PYZus{}1/Dynamo/KT15/Dynamo\PYZus{}KT15\PYZus{}7409\PYZus{}7417.cdf}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{,}

         \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{}New version using sky correction but no calibration}

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{outcolor}Out[{\color{outcolor}44}]:} Text(0.5, 1.0, 'Sea Snake vs. KT15 for all Dynamo Data')
\end{Verbatim}
            
    \begin{center}
    \adjustimage{max size={0.9\linewidth}{0.9\paperheight}}{output_9_1.png}
    \end{center}
    { \hspace*{\fill} \\}
    
    In conclusion, I think we should proceed with the two high-temperature
calibrations for the DYNAMO analysis. Moving forward we need to develop
a calibration process that spans the full range of housing/ambient
temperatures in addition to just varying the blackbody target
temperatures.


    % Add a bibliography block to the postdoc
    
    
    
    \end{document}
